channel.title: Overclocking
channel.description:
I want to overclock my cpu, i have a quad core intel 2.88ghz processor (Q9550 i believe).
and i have never done it before, i am computer literate and would like soem advice and steps of what i should do and any errors i should look out for!
all help is welcomed! thanks, Ollie.

item.title: Overclocking
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

la­wl:

buying a new fan before trying it with stock fan = dumb

the fan i bought was larger as the initial plan is to make it quieter, however the advantage of overclocking has now sprung.]

Moparisthebest:

The question is why do you want to do it? Sure you can, but will it really give you any advantages? Chances are the answer is no.

I recently purchased kaspersky internet security and it uses a small amount of CPU, i would like to use this aswell as maintain my original cpu stats, i use it for graphic design, render and website building. oh and the occsional game

the answer is that i probably dont need it, but if my cpu can handle it as the overhead on the new CPU’s are huge compared to what they used to be, why not?

Read full topic

item.title: Overclocking
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

Hi thanks, i purchased a coolmaster cpu fan last week in anticipation, it seemed to have good reviews.

I was only wanting to clock to about 3.1-3.2Ghz anyway so it seems my processor will be able to do so, i will post results when i get home from work and give it a try.

I am assuming the options to change the volgate, fsb and clockspeed will be in the bios?

thanks for your help.

Read full topic

item.title: Overclocking
item.dc:creator: @xEnt xEnt
item.description:
@xEnt wrote:

use OCCT (over clock checking tool) to stress your overclocked CPU for about an hour, it will auto stop and fail the test once it reaches 70c (max you’d wanna get)

Read full topic

item.title: Overclocking
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

Buy the biggest cooler you can find. (Zalman do good coolders)
Upgrade BIOS
Check which voltages your cpu operate
Change multiplier, fsb etc before you change voltages.
Overclock slowly, go in increments of about 100-200Mhz.
Keep idle temp below 60C and load temp < 80C

Seems you could get to 3.6Ghz…

We tweaked some voltages and settings and were able to boot to a front side bus (FSB) speed of 400 MHz on the first try and a 3.4 GHz CPU speed. Encouraged, we tried to up the bus speed but encountered crashing.

We set the Vcore to 1.35 V and to 1.3 V for the CPU termination, MCH core, and ICH core. Memory was upped slightly to 1.9 V, and we limited the PCI Express (PCIe) bus to 100 MHz. We turned off virtualization and thermal throttling as well. With these settings we were able to set the FSB to 425 MHz, for a 3.61 GHz clock speed.

Without pushing further, we wanted to see how hot and stable the system was at this speed, so we performed some Prime95 testing. While the system was completely stable, the Speedfan monitoring application reported temperatures of 77 degrees Celsius at load. Since we accepted high temperatures in our Core i7 920 testing from our last SBM (and considering that the CPU would probably never be stressed that hard except in a synthetic benchmark like Prime95), we continued with the ~800 MHz overclock and called it a day. A clock speed of 3.62 GHz is an acceptable overclock for a Q9550 on air and we wanted to produce some results that a buyer might reasonably expect from similar components.


Tom's Hardware – 11 Feb 09

Assembly And Overclocking - System Builder Marathon: $1,250 Mid-Range PC

This time around, with an established Core 2 Quad CPU and P45-based motherboard, we have very little to report about the hardware assembly and operating system installation. All of the components fit inside the Rosewill Wind Ryd...

Read full topic
